data.text: "content" and "media" may end as terms, as we simply enjoy personalized experiences, not productize or distribute uniform consumables. centralized production for many is replaced by decentralized production for each individual human. should be fun.

community will likely still matter (shared content experiences), but not in its current form. perhaps we each experience a storyline in a global story/movie/game, or tweak segments of a master song to our own preferences (more drum solos!).. but then that too may feel arcane..

this doesn't seem feasible today but as AI models train on "emotion", they may move away from objective (extended) mimicry to producing something that starts to feel novel, perhaps more novel than human creators, and then things will change fast..

everyone will enjoy their own personalized movie, music, book, news article, video game experience. it may seem silly one day that many humans listened to the same piece of music, watched the same movie, read the same book...
it seems more likely that AI won't replace the creator in the traditional model but rather will become the personalized content creator for each individual...
i think what some predictors have wrong about generative AI is the expectation that it will create content in its current one-to-many form - one movie, one piece of music, a book, consumed by many...
@_rachelbraun @nickcalacanis agree completely. @nickcalacanis is a hero. @theallinpod is built on the back of his amazing work ethic
@RyanCrownholm @theallinpod @chamath @Jason @DavidSacks @prenuvo really glad you caught it and are ok! such a great motivator to keep doing the pod. thanks for sharing
i just can’t stop AI’ing…
that got dark fast... https://t.co/lAjaA50Gh7
tomorrow's @theallinpod is done before it's recorded... cc @Jason @DavidSacks @chamath @sama https://t.co/AUV6Ya8iiB
RT @TerribleMaps: World map according to fish https://t.co/4Gd8A0q2RF
@pmarca def not comprehensive as to the problems or the conditions that got us here.
@AustinTani @all_in_tok inevitable
@itsMattMac saving the $100/yr to donate to @HumaneSociety
@dee_bosa @kaleandquinoa @CNBCTechCheck @eToro @Akamai @GenDigitalInc @eToroUS @TomLeightonAKAM i am a huge @dee_bosa fan. she was the only reporter to admit to prankster blunder!
@Jason why can’t we ever have these conversations in private first?
@FabreTillman “echo chamber on/off” should be a filter

but the past few years have shown us that authority-driven journalism won't be the standard going forward. 

i hope, and expect, that the open internet, and whatever platforms enable fact-finding, discovery, and truth, will win out over the sensational, the moderated, the closed
so, eventually all content may find its way to distributed systems. esp if governments begin excessively intervening in the content moderation schema of platforms.
whether open platforms will work in a centralized or decentralized model, i don't know. shareholders may eventually have to kowtow to regulatory bodies.

ML-based tagging, as has been done so well at youtube, can create a framework for making this better experience; active filtering using those tags should required by the reader in order to engage the service.

by shifting responsibility to the reader, to clearly state what they do, and do not, want to see and read, and revealing to them what other readers "think" about particular content, perhaps we can engage people to think differently and have a more rounded discourse.

i believe that platforms must create tools that shift responsibility from the citizen journalist (no policing of content) to the reader - with strong tools for filtering, preference, and influence selection being the core offering of the platform. not viral engagement.

but yes, open platforms can quickly devolve into Lord of the Flies.. the desire for sensational content and the mechanism of groupthink can quickly make the untrue the accepted truth. how to avoid this?
and through citizen journalism, perhaps, the truth can be revealed better than it may be through the service of a handful of trusted moderators who are increasingly inclined to the sensational.

and this is why more open platforms are so important - they offer a chance for any citizen of the service to say, or show, what they see, hear, feel without the approval of the journalist, or a moderator.
since COVID, some of what was chastised as conspiracy theory, fringe thinking, and fake news, at the time, turned out to be, maybe, just a little bit right.

the unaffiliated individual reporting some as-yet unseen fact, and the citizenry, en masse, discovering truth, together, IS the new media. 

this is the manifestation of the promise of the open internet. and it is vital.

the journalistic void seems to have been, and is being, filled by citizen journalism - from internet sleuths, cell phone videographers, home office analysts, sharing their fact-finding across twitter, youtube, discord and reddit..

sensational stories are simply better business than the boring truth. 

(side note: props to @rahul_ligma_ for superb trolling!)

today, the truth doesn't matter as much as the sensational. we all see this - modern mass media "journalism" is simply oriented around sensationalism. the topics, theses, content need to excite some emotion or it won't find a viewer and, thus, can't become relevant "news"...

the reporting of "fired twitter employees" (which turned out to be pranksters) was neither verified nor supported by other investigated facts. "journalists" simply repeated untruths across live media. why? because it was sensational...
what defines a "journalist" today? does a person repeating what someone else said, without taking steps to verify their statement, qualify? ...
@Jason @elonmusk Chief Customer Disservice Officer

maybe i can get that verified emoji now
cc @elonmusk (+ @jason)
@zebulgar lol
if we are going to balkanize everything, maybe we should build replacement systems for the globally-interdependent ones first
if, after all our bickering and disagreements, we can make it to episode 100, i have faith the world will make it too! congrats on ep100 besties @chamath @DavidSacks @Jason https://t.co/KNsNTalXPv

feels like contagion territory. taking so much capital out of the global capital network, and turning off so many nodes on that network, so fast.. non-zero chance of feedback loops and cascades we don’t see yet.
@duncan__c deregulate
@oconnoreugene1 @Jason @theallinpod you will. yamanaka factors ftw
@joshu neutron beams directed at the moon should solve our local heat problem
@towgc there will always be something
@joshu turbines -> electricity -> batteries? these are controlled systems
@joshu current plasma fusion system plans are to disperse heat into water to drive turbines... energy can be reasonably conserved (and created)

for these reasons, and others (driven by various other science/eng advances), i am optimistic about mankind's ability to survive and thrive through the end of this century and well into the next, at which point, it appears far more than we can imagine today may become possible..

what would our species pursue with abundant cheap heavy elements? that's not clear today, but new technologies would generally be more accessible/feasible; interstellar travel would certainly be easier (atoms on a star ship could be recycled/converted).

entire industries in the 22nd century could be built around terrestrial nucleosynthesis. prices would be driven down on anything "rare" today, and operators of these next-gen commodity-producing systems could sit at the helm of new economies.

rare would become abundant. this notion of "terrestrial nucleosynthesis" hasn't been discussed much in the context of plasma fusion systems but to me represents one of the greatest next-gen unlocks after abundant free energy.

plasma fusion systems should eventually get denser, hotter, more energetic, yielding an ability to not just generate electricity, but to drive collisions of small particles into bigger and bigger nuclei... we could eventually "synthesize" heavy elements here on Earth!

"rare earth elements" (used in batteries & electronics) are very hard to find/mine; phosphorus (a fertilizer critical to growing all our crops on Earth) will be fully mined out of Earth's crust in ~100 years. etc
however, in a post-plasma fusion world, things could be different..

produced from the dense energy inside stars that exploded billions of years before the formation of Earth (and were part of our planet's formation), we've always assumed heavier elements here on Earth were fixed natural resources - we can't just make more

in stars, over time, as protons and neutrons and bigger nuclei collide with each other under extreme energy and pressure, bigger and bigger nuclei are formed - all heavier elements (heavier than hydrogen) are formed this way. carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, iron, lithium, nedoymium etc

as we move past the 21st century and plasma fusion, like all technologies, becomes faster, cheaper, smaller, better, its application set will expand beyond its original obvious purpose. to what? well, remember, plasma fusion is fundamentally the system of stars...

we tend to think about new technologies linearly.. their obvious application solving a problem directly in front of us. but more often than not, the value realized from new tech is its utilization across novel applications.

urls.title: AlphaFold reveals the structure of the protein universe
urls.description: Today, in partnership with EMBL’s European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI), we’re now releasing predicted structures for nearly all catalogued proteins known to science, which will expand the AlphaFold DB by over 200x - from nearly 1 million structures to over 200 million structures - with the potential to dramatically increase our understanding of biology.

tweets.text:
A year ago we open-sourced #AlphaFold

Today we're freely sharing the predicted structures of all 200M+ proteins known to science - almost the entire protein universe!

It's our gift to humanity, and a demonstration of the benefits AI can bring to society
https://t.co/G8vj8sbTcN

urls.title: Opinion | Jerome Powell’s Fed Pursues a Painful and Ineffective Inflation Cure
urls.description: More aggressive interest-rate hikes will cost millions of jobs and won’t address the causes of high prices.

tweets.text:
.@SenWarren's attacks on the @federalreserve's monetary policy and my economic analysis are, I believe, misguided and if heeded could have devastating consequences for tens of millions of workers.

@friedberg if you drive a motor with the batteries, the inefficient part of the system bleeds heat into the system. in long term it all ends up diffused into the ecosystem. and radiative cooling is already way too slow.
@friedberg But then what will we fight over?

@friedberg right but that heat still gets dissipated into the local environment. the earth doesn’t radiate enough heat off into space. if we made considerably more energy (through clean fusion, say) it still becomes a problem. not sure how it gets conserved here
@friedberg remember that using a lot of power will dissipate a great deal of heat that may not be so easy to get rid of

what would our species pursue with abundant cheap heavy elements? that's not clear today, but new technologies would generally be more accessible/feasible; interstellar travel would certainly be easier (atoms on a star ship could be recycled/converted).

entire industries in the 22nd century could be built around terrestrial nucleosynthesis. prices would be driven down on anything "rare" today, and operators of these next-gen commodity-producing systems could sit at the helm of new economies.

rare would become abundant. this notion of "terrestrial nucleosynthesis" hasn't been discussed much in the context of plasma fusion systems but to me represents one of the greatest next-gen unlocks after abundant free energy.

plasma fusion systems should eventually get denser, hotter, more energetic, yielding an ability to not just generate electricity, but to drive collisions of small particles into bigger and bigger nuclei... we could eventually "synthesize" heavy elements here on Earth!

"rare earth elements" (used in batteries & electronics) are very hard to find/mine; phosphorus (a fertilizer critical to growing all our crops on Earth) will be fully mined out of Earth's crust in ~100 years. etc
however, in a post-plasma fusion world, things could be different..

produced from the dense energy inside stars that exploded billions of years before the formation of Earth (and were part of our planet's formation), we've always assumed heavier elements here on Earth were fixed natural resources - we can't just make more

in stars, over time, as protons and neutrons and bigger nuclei collide with each other under extreme energy and pressure, bigger and bigger nuclei are formed - all heavier elements (heavier than hydrogen) are formed this way. carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, iron, lithium, nedoymium etc

as we move past the 21st century and plasma fusion, like all technologies, becomes faster, cheaper, smaller, better, its application set will expand beyond its original obvious purpose. to what? well, remember, plasma fusion is fundamentally the system of stars...

we tend to think about new technologies linearly.. their obvious application solving a problem directly in front of us. but more often than not, the value realized from new tech is its utilization across novel applications.
as the 21st century progresses, plasma fusion could be the technology savior of our species and our planet, but it could also be the enabler of previously unconsidered opportunities.
